Their husbands were Henry's age, so we were kind of the three couples, the six of us. The funny thing is that they were all from outside; they were not Washingtonians. One, Shirley, was from Allentown, Pennsylvania and the other was from New York. So that made it that was our kind of bond, and we became very friendly. And we stayed friends till this day, as a matter of fact. These were my first friends in Washington, and in 1954, | think, | had my daughter. | became, you know, | gave birth to my daughter. That was five years after we were married, and then about a year and a half later, | had Craig, we had Craig. And we had the townhouse, a little townhouse, a semi-detached home in Silver Spring not far from here. And | was doing absolutely one thing, | was saving money to go to Israel. By that time, of course, my sister was already married. She had two children, her husband had already been in the War of Independence. And we were in contact all the time, | was forever sending packages. Times were rough in Israel, in Palestine. | mean in comparison, | was rich. But | was saving money to go to Israel, and in 1959 | took my five-year-old daughter and three-and-a-half-year-old son; in March of '59, we went to Israel. | took a ship, | had to because | was taking an awful lot of stuff with me. As | said, things were rough in Israel. And | went to Israel, and | spent -- | left my poor husband for all this time. He came for a month, actually. I'm sorry, he was gone a month. He had, at that point, he had started working and had left Berikson. He was working for the National Cotton Council, and it was a very good job. And he had some trips that he needed to take to Europe, so he came to Israel. But | was in Israel from March to September 19- -- | was in Israel for a half a year. | saw my girlfriend, Esther, of course, who was by that time married and had a little boy. And | was with my sister, she had three children at that point and | fell in love with Israel. At that point, | think that's when | started making peace with God a little bit. | walked the streets of Es Salt and Jerusalem. | walked into the first synagogue that was in Jerusalem, and my sister who was not religious would light Shabbat candles. She wouldn't say a prayer, she would say, "Shabbat, Shalom." And | thought this was a very nice custom for a beginning for me, and | started -- | became very interested. | always loved history. I's funny, you said you liked it because | always like history, always loved archeology. If my life had normally, when | was child | used to tell my father that I'm going to be an archeologist, | didn't do that. But when | came back from Israel, | had already been enrolled. | was going to night school in Maryland, and | seriously thought of becoming an accountant. | thought it would be a good thing to do, | wouldn't have to work maybe full-time, you know, raising kids. But | switched, | decided to study Hebrew. And | started to really, | started studying Torah. | enrolled at Baltimore Hebrew College. | took all my courses there in Hebrew. | got my degree in Hebrew letters, and | became a licensed Hebrew teacher. And while | was going to school, | started teaching Hebrew in different synagogues. For a while | taught at Northwood when they had Hebrew as a language. And then the last 10 years before | retired, | was supervising the Hebrew Department at Washington Hebrew Congregation, so that was my last -- but studying Hebrew, studying Torah, studying the town, | did it a lot of reading. And | also for the first time, | did not before, | didn't talk much about the Holocaust and | didn't read much. | started reading a lot.

segments.question: When?
segments.answer: | started -- well, it kind of came together. | needed to understand, | needed to understand a little bit. | couldn't make peace with the Holocaust emotionally myself. | don't think anyone -- occasionally, sometimes, you know, if they tell you, you know, that a therapist or a psychologist or a psychiatrist can help. These are not problems that a psychiatrist can -- | mean there was nothing that | could work out with a psychiatrist. It isn't that | needed to understand why my mother didn't treat me right or | didn't -- there wasn't anything like that. To understand the Holocaust, you can't understand the Holocaust. In other words, | can't imagine that anybody can be helped by a psychiatrist in terms of the experiences of the Holocaust. Perhaps some people, if they have some guilt relate it to the Holocaust. I'll be very honest with you, | never felt guilty that | survived and some didn't. Because | didn't survive, | didn't do anything to anybody to survive. | survived by sheer luck. Some Holocaust survivors have this guilt, even if they survived the same way as | did. | don't know why. Maybe that kind of a thing can be cleared up or helped through some therapy, just to understand that there's no guilt in having survived. On the contrary, if anything, perhaps a little triumph that Hitler didn't accomplish everything, that somehow we're here. And, you know, | married and | have a son and a daughter, so, you know, why should | feel guilty about that? But to go somewhere and try to understand and to make peace with the Holocaust on an emotional level, | don't try and | can't. When | get a bad dream, when | have a nightmare, | either take a pill or | get up and read a book. Henry does it all the time. When he sees his father's face -- he doesn't tell me much, but | Know that he was -- the last person, he was Auschwitz with his father, and he can't get rid of that face. He sees his father with that -- once in a while, he tells me that he sees his father because they were on a train together, and he had this three, four-day, you know, gray growth. And his father gave him something that he had, they came out of the ghetto of Lodz. That was a horrible place to begin with, and so he didn't have much. Maybe he had some cigars and maybe he had some -- maybe he a silver dollar or something. And he gave it to Henry and he said, "Take it. | don't need it anymore." Or something. And | know when Henry has that dream or when he sees this, he just gets out of bed. | don't ask him. Goes down to the den. Take a crime story and he reads. You can't solve anything about that. But | needed to solve for myself, | don't mean solve. | needed to understand how God could permit that. Now, Henry doesn't have this problem because | think he's an atheist or he’ an agnostic. So he's not asking God how God could allow it. Insofar as he's concerned, he has an expression, he says, "Shit falls." Look what's going on all over the world. There are people killing people in other places. So maybe in that sense he doesn't have, but | have -- I'm not an agnostic. | have some kind of a belief, | don't necessarily believe in a Jewish God. | believe in a Supreme -- | believe in God. So | have to figure out for myself, | had to, how this could happen. And they way | have solved it, and | think I've said that perhaps in other places, when | read a book by Dr. Fakenheim (ph), Professor Fakenheim, | think he was a professor at the University of -- Canadian. There's a University in Canada, I'm trying to remember. | don't remember the name. Anyway, he was a professor of history in Canada. He now | think is a professor in Moretus in Jerusalem. And he wrote a book, "God's Place in History." | don't remember exactly, you may not. And he said something in the book, and it's absolutely true. He said that God was not in Auschwitz, that God gave us -- when you speak to the Jews, he gave us the Torah, but that's not important. He gave, he taught people what is right and what is wrong. And if we choose to do the wrong thing, then we do it. And God didn't create Auschwitz, the Germans did. And what happened in Auschwitz was between the Germans and their victims. And now, perhaps in the earlier history, according to Fakenheim, did interfere. He took us out of Egypt, but that was a god of a different time. In our time, God does not interfere. So | have that kind of a peace with myself that | don't blame God for Auschwitz; | blame the Germans for Auschwitz. Just as | blame, just as | will put the blame of the people who kill each other in Burundi, Rwanda, Yugoslavia.

segments.question: | want to ask you something that you have not spoken about, okay. First of all, | wanted to ask you this because to so many survivors it's an issue. And that is did you talk to your children about your experience? And if you did, when did you and why did you? And if you didn't, why didn't you?
segments.answer: Oh, okay. Well, you know, it would be nice if my daughter could -- because | sometimes talk to her about it. | did talk to my children. | think at different times, and it depended -- when the reason came. | didn't live it all the time with them. Actually, when the kids were little, when they were growing up in the house, these were really happy times for us in many ways. But | talked to them because when they were little, and they wanted to know, for instance, why Lisa Zidner has a grandmother who's coming to visit and Janie has a grandpa and grandma coming, and where are my parents and where are Henry's parents? So | told them that both my parents and Daddy's parents are not alive. Why aren't they alive? | said, "Well, they died in the war." "How did they die?" "Well, they didn't die -- they died because of the war. And when you will be bigger, | will explain it.". And | did, and, of course, in 1959 they were in Israel with me, and we talked a little bit more about it. The children were still little. When they got bigger -- and | did. For instance, on Tu B'Shevat, | always lit candles. That | did even though | didn't go to a synagogue because this was the anniversary of the destruction of my ghetto. So | lit candles, and when the kids were big enough and they would ask me why I'm doing it. And | told them I'm lighting the candles to remember my mom and my father and my sister and my brother. And as they were getting bigger, | would tell them about some of the things that happened to me. Depending on their age when they got big enough. Henry did much less of it. He had a lot of trouble talking about it. On the other hand, and | did discuss this with my daughter, | asked her whether she feels - because | wanted to know. That was some many years later, whether she was -- when | read the book my Helen Epstein, did you read it? Helen Epstein wrote a book called, "The Children of the Holocaust." | think she wrote about that second generation. And | was very upset when | read the book, because apparently she wrote the book, she based it upon a study that was done. Or maybe she did the study, discussing it with a psychiatrist or some psychiatrist in Boston, whose children -- whose patients were children of Holocaust survivors. And she paints a picture of real neurotic, disturbed children, and | was upset. First of all, the first thing | did at that point, | wanted to know from my daughter and from my son whether something like this -- after all, no matter how objective you think you are, you're not objective, you know. Did I? Did | fill them with these kind of -- some of the stories that she writes about, you know, these children really grew up in very dysfunctional, difficult homes. So | talked to my kids, and both my children told me, and this was not right away, but through the years; this is the picture | got from them. That theirs was a happy childhood, that they had a good home. That they were aware of a lot of things and they were not totally not affected. In other words, okay, in other words, what they -- then, as a matter of fact, let me tell you how they saw. That they were not to be compared with the children that Helen Epstein is talking about fully. And, in fact, it was Robbi (ph) who came out, my daughter, with the idea that perhaps we were lucky, Henry and |. We had survived the Holocaust and we were young. | had lost my parents, lost my sister and my brother, but | didn't lose a husband and | didn't lose children. Many of the children described in Helen's books were raised as second children. They were raised by people who had lost not just their past, but their future. Some of these people lost their children. Later | met some -- | know some people were -- sorry. Robbi had a friend who told her -- he was a Survivor's son -- that he didn't know that he had a sister until his father was on his death bed. When his father was dying, he told him that before the war, he was married and he had a daughter. Why these people could not deal with it, | don't know. | belonged to the generation, and there were many like me, who survived the war and did not lose husbands and children. | was too young for that. That may have made a difference. | think that for anybody who studies the Holocaust survivors, | think they should draw that line. That was more difficult for people who had that. So in that sense, I'm not taking any credit, it may have been easier. Did my children -- were my children affected by some of it? Definitely. In what way? Well, first of all, the fact that Henry did not talk was not very good. It would have helped if he did. On the other hand, | can't say that he never talked. He talked about before the war how things were at home. He just didn't talk about Auschwitz, he couldn't. And that was probably -- but | did. And | think that was -- Robbi always felt that that was good. That | had, that they didn't have to imagine things being worse than they were, so that was helpful. On the other hand, Robbi said that | was neurotic about certain things, and, for instance, | was probably overprotective. | tried not to be. Up here, | tried not to be. | sent my son and my daughter -- my daughter was 10 years old when she went for four weeks to camp, and my son was nine and a half. In other words, | sent them to camp away from home. | gave them a lot of freedom. | did not -- but that was up here. Emotionally, | suppose if Robbi was late from school, | may have been a little more upset than | should have. Fortunately, even though Henry did not -- Henry acted in this sense as good balance. When I, when we went -- when the kids learned how to swim and we'd be going to a swimming pool and | would go with the kids, and they learned how to jump from the, what is it? From the diving board. And so we made an agreement, so | said to them, "Okay, when I'm not here, you can't jump off the diving board. You can swim." And so the kids said, "Why? Why can't we? We're good swimmers." By the way, I'm not a swimmer. | can float. So when we came home, but | said, "No, | won't allow you when I'm not here." So the kids as usually they would take their case to their father. So they would say to Henry, "Daddy, Mom won't let us jump off the diving board when she's not there." So Henry looked at me and he said, "Bella, tell me what is the difference?" First of all, he thought it was funny. He said, "What could you do for them if you were there watching?" So that was already -- but anyway, | said, "Well, I'll feel better if I'm there. I'll holler for help." Well, anyway, this was said to me. Henry said to me, "You can either be there all the time, but you cannot restrict them." So that was settled, and this was how we settled some of theses. So yeah, | had some, | wouldn't let Craig ride a bike to the library until Henry said that this is crazy, and then Craig rode the bike to the library. But we settled this.

segments.question: You negotiated together?
segments.answer: Yeah, we did, we did. Yeah, we did. On the other hand, when Craig went to Harvard, he didn't tell me. This is how | found out about the book. He took a course on the Holocaust. He has a library on the Holocaust. That's not his field, but, you know, this his interest. There's no question. So were the kids affected? | think so, definitely. But perhaps not in a totally damaging way, | don't think so. | hope not. My daughter had some problems, but | don't think they had anything to do with the Holocaust. In fact, she used to say to me that when she had -- she had a chemical disorder. She had a premenstrual, what is it? Premenstrual syndrome, PMS, that led practically to depression until they finally medicated her. It was just totally uncalled for, because it wasn't recognized. But she said to me that it got to a point that when she was in Princeton and she started having problems. And she would go for help, and she said, "Mom, | got to a point where | wouldn't tell them that I'm a Holocaust survivor's child, because they would get into it, " and she said, "and my problem had nothing to do with the Holocaust."

segments.question: So she was aware of...
segments.answer: Yeah. But as | say, she's fine. And she's on medication, but if it hadn't been neglected. She had some rough years because of that. But it was, she said on the other hand, she probably is a little bit more high-strung than she would have been if she hadn't been raised in a house by a mother who, when the phone ring, | would jump. So...

segments.question: And now that your children are adults and out of the house and it's just you and your husband, does he talk more? Do you talk more to other people about what you went through? Is it even a different phase of your life now in your own thinking about the Holocaust?
segments.answer: Well, this has been a process. As | told you, originally, | did not talk about the Holocaust at all. | started talking about it. That was right awaya...

data: We need to switch tapes here. End of Tape 2. Tape 3

segments.question: This is Tape 3 of an interview with Bella Tovey on June 6th, 1996 -- June 10th, 1996. The question that | started to ask at the end of Tape 2 was, your children have left home now, and you and your husband are here together, and how is your thinking about the Holocaust today, compared to when you had children at home, or when they were young? Where are you now in your thinking about it?
segments.answer: Well, mostly, as | said, | didn't -- we don't, Henry and | -- it's funny. We don't talk about the Holocaust. | can talk to Henry about it, although | will say this: In 19- -- there are a couple of things that happened. First of all, | talk about the Holocaust more mostly because -- and | started originally when | was a Hebrew teacher talking to my class. First | talked to my children at home. Then | talked - but mostly that's why | agreed to interviews, | gave my oral history. When | started reading that people were denying that the Holocaust happened, | think | took, | made a definite decision that | need to make some kind of a contribution if | can, because | realize that there are people who are denying that the Holocaust happened. And particularly | remember reading about a Professor Butz, B-u-t-z, | think. He was at the University of Northwestern, and he wrote a book called "The Hoax of the Twentieth Century," denying. In other words, this is not just, you know, some of these skinheads denying the Holocaust. But this is scholarly work being written that the Holocaust never took place. It's that kind of a thing that made me want to do it. That, plus the fact that we did take Roberta and Craig to Poland in 1989, shortly after Henry retired. We went back to my city, to Henry's city, went to Auschwitz. We went to all of these places. We went to Mogilev. Our son and our daughter wanted, they felt it was an incredible experience. My husband paid for it by becoming -- and he's never been depressed. He was depressed for three months after we came home. It was a rough trip for him. He did it for his kids, and it was at that time that he talked about his experiences because it was -- | mean we were in Auschwitz.

segments.question: To the kids?
segments.answer: Yeah, to the kids. Most of the time Henry and | do not talk about it. When I'm called up occasionally by the Children's Museum, | go and talk, because | feel it's important. | gave a talk at my temple a couple of years ago. Henry actually gave a talk once in his life last year at the Liberation. We had a wonderful service dedicated to the liberators last year, and Henry was one of the people who the rabbi -- Henry's very fond of our rabbi, so he twisted his arm, and Henry gave a short talk. That was the only time that Henry talked. | will also say to you, though, that when some of my friends who are survivors -- | don't have too many friends here. | have one couple, but we have some friends who occasionally come from New York. When we get together, usually, and this is kind of a joke and a password. That one of our friends will say, "Well, we came to Auschwitz. Why don't we go home? Why don't we go to sleep?" In other words, if | can explain what happens, yeah. | think that when we are together, particularly with people who went through what we did, we find ourselves somehow drifting back. And usually somebody then will say, "Okay, we're already in Auschwitz. Why don't we call it quits? And why don't we go to sleep?"

segments.question: | don't understand that.
segments.answer: What happens is that we are together. We can be talking about our kids, we can be talking about politics. Henry and | volunteered this days in the Whitehouse, and we are very, very pro-Clinton, for instance, so we talk about politics. We can talk about music. My husband loves birds. We can be talking, and then suddenly somebody will say something, remember something that happened. And then we'll start talking about -- and one thing leads into the other, he'll mention something, then we start talking about the Holocaust. And then somebody will usually say, "Well, we are in Auschwitz. Why don't we go to sleep?" Meaning, that somehow Auschwitz is the, what is it, is the synonymous thing with Holocaust. So we got to Auschwitz, why don't we call it quits? Why don't we stop talking?

segments.question: Meaning, let's not talk about this anymore?
segments.answer: Meaning that somehow it's -- no matter what we talk about, when we are together with people who went through what we went through, we somehow end up getting to Auschwitz. So yeah, can | say that we do? Yeah, we do. Somehow it didn't leave us. | remember you have on that big film, the big one in the Holocaust Museum, somebody said that she tries not to teach her children to hate. | never taught my kids to hate. And if they want to forgive, my son is flying to Israel today. | hope he has a good trip, and he's so happens that his trip is paid for by his University. And the tickets, he's going via Frankfort with Lufthansa. And from there | think he's taking via -- to Israel, but he's stopping in Frankfort for a day. | will not go to Germany. My son is going, he isn't going to visit Germany, but he is going to go through Frankfort and go on. It's okay.

segments.question: Because you still have...
segments.answer: It's okay for him, and it's fine, but | will not go to Germany. | will not forget and I'm not forgiving. Not where the Germans are concerned. So am | left with something? Yeah, probably.

segments.question: Do you have grandchildren yet?
segments.answer: My son has three adopted children.

segments.question: Are they old enough to ask questions?
segments.answer: Probably, but we haven't gotten to talk about it. His oldest daughter is 10 and a half. Two are from Korea; one is from Peru. And Kendall is going with Craig to Israel, so | don't know. I'm sure that Craig has talked to her about it.

segments.question: It would be interesting maybe as they get older to see how you think about talking to them.
segments.answer: | don't know. Come to think of it, we have talked a little bit because they come home for Passover, and it is during Passover that we talk a little bit about it. As a matter of fact, last year | was 50 years when we were liberated, and Robbi and Craig, our son and our daughter, and my son-in-law -- my son is divorced -- planted 50 trees, 100 trees, excuse me for us in Israel; 50 for me and 50 for Henry in honor of our liberation. So we talked about being liberated and our children and grandchildren were here, so we do talk a little bit about it already.

segments.question: How did your relationship with your sister turn out?
segments.answer: Great. | have a wonderful relationship with my sister. My sister did what she needed to do, and as | said, once | came to America, | did not take a walk to Israel. | did not go to Israel, | settled here. I've pretty lucky in this country. It's been a great country for us. | have some moments where | feel that perhaps | should have gone to Israel. Because | think that maybe all Jewish people should be in Israel, but it's nice coming to America. | have my -- as | say, | have my mixed feelings occasionally. But this is by now my country, so in that sense | think I'm like many of the first, what is it, immigrant Americans. I'm probably more patriotic than even my children. | find that Americans don't appreciate this country as much as people who have come here. And | mean that honestly, with all its faults, this is a truly great country. A very democratic country. There's some problems, problems everywhere. Wasn't it Churchill that said it's the worst of the best systems? Oh, no. He said something. It's a bad system, but it's the best of all the bad ones.

segments.question: It's come to my conscience here about a year or so, especially last winter during the presidential primaries, you probably are -- my assumption is that you are sensitive to hearing anti-Semitism expressed by political figures or aspiring political figures. How does your experience play itself out in your political view of your life here? Or maybe it doesn't.
segments.answer: Well, | am sensitive to it, and for instance, definitely wnen | make my decisions about voting, | am very careful to -- | definitely am sensitive to anti-Semitic or even, you know, that kind of an expression. Henry worked with non-Jews most of his life, and some of them were truly wonderful people who had no -- they were not prejudiced. But he had friends who would occasionally say | Jewed him down or something. And when it comes to political people, | could not stand Baker. | thought that the Bush administration was -- and it's not because they were Republicans. Reagan had his faults, God knows. | didn't care for some of his politics, but he was not an anti-Semitic. Bush was an anti-Semitic, he was a kind of an aristocratic anti-Semitic, if you will. And Baker, even worse. Clinton is- maybe that's why -- that's not the only reason I'm fond of him, but Clinton with all of his faults -- they accuse him of so many terrible things, but | think he's basically a totally unprejudiced man. And to me -- to me, this is more important than anything else. | don't worry about relationships between, I'm not God. I'm not telling people how to live. | don't care whether Clinton has a mistress or will have a mistress, that's not my business. | think that the most important thing about a human being is to be fully accepting of other human beings. And | treasure people who are able to see human beings as human beings regardless of the color and religion and whatever. And Clinton, to me, with all of his faults, and God knows he's got lots of faults; everybody does. Clinton is a truly unprejudiced man. | sometimes wonder whether hopefully maybe this is true for this younger generation. My daughter, for instance, | have some non-Jewish friends, but not that many. We had more when Henry was working. Robbi, even though she belongs to a temple and she's Jewish in the sense that she's more observant that | am, 50 percent of her friends are not Jewish. And maybe your generation is less prejudiced, maybe you have -- although God knows that's probably not true. | work in the Whitehouse, and | hear all kinds of things when | answer the phones. But to me, this is the most important thing about a person.

segments.question: Is this something that you learned from your parents or something that you learned as a result of your experience?
segments.answer: What? Not appreciating a human being who can be without a prejudice? I'm trying to think. My father was a very tolerant man. My father was a religious Jew. My father was a very tolerant person. When people would come and say that they saw a friend's son smoking on Shabbat, and my father did not smoke on Shabbat. He would say, "What's the matter? Only the non-observant have a right to smoke on Shabbat?" So | probably grew up in a very tolerant home. That may have been, but | think that the war had a lot to do with it, too. There's no question. | mean our mind is a reaction. When | meet people who survived the Holocaust, and there are some of us, who will say -- although | think if they start thinking, they wouldn't -- who will say something derogatory about blacks or something. | get terribly upset, | think that we have absolutely -- if we didn't take anything out of those camps, we have to remember that we are all human beings. And we have to remember something else, that it's so important, it's so important not to allow yourself a kind of a -- if people think that just saying something negative about another person is not dangerous, they're wrong. | think that the minute you open up the possibility that somebody is not quite worthy of the same treatment as you are -- I'm always that when | talk to children and, you know, when | talk to any groups, that when somebody will try to take away one right, when somebody will try to tell you that you are not entitled to one thing of all the thousands things that other people are entitled, that's the beginning of the end. | think we all have to be so sensitive to it. To me, this is so important that every human being has to have the same rights. And we have no right, | have no -- if | sometimes, think, you know, if | get angry at something or, you know, when | hear these stories about welfare, it doesn't matter that there are more blacks who are on welfare. It doesn't matter. Use the words that there are more people in New York who are on welfare, but don't put the labels of black, white, green, yellow. I'm very proud of the fact that my son adopted two children from Korea and one child from Peru. It means that he grew up ina home where he didn't hear that being Jewish is better than anything else.

segments.question: And yet, you told me an hour ago that when you, in 1945, you couldn't stand the sight of German children, so you've made a lot of -- you've sort of come a long way in your thinking. That's different?
segments.answer: No, no. That's different. Let me explain. When | said in 1945 that | had to get out of Germany, | emotionally was very troubled. | adored my kid sister, and | lost a kid sister and a kid brother. My brother was born in 1933, and he was 10 years old when he was taken to Auschwitz. | wasn't home anymore, and my sister was 12 years old. | lost two children, my younger siblings, and when | saw families -- and | lost my parents. And when | would occasionally get out of Bergen and | saw people, normal people -- a father and a mother and a couple of children -- walking on the street, and they took that away from me. And they did it, so yeah, | hated them. And frankly, | was afraid -- | didn't want to stay in Germany; | didn't want to hate that much, and | didn't know where that hatred would bring me to. | don't think that | would have gone out and killed somebody, but I'll tell you this: When | heard, because | wasn't involved, when | heard that the inmates in Bergen-Belsen put a couple of barracks on fire where the SS men were put in. When the British came in, they took some of the SS men who didn't manage to escape and put them in a barrack and they surrounded them. And then some of the prisoners who can walk, some of us had -- not all of us were in my shape. They put those barracks on fire, and the British soldiers walked away. Of course, they later, the prisoners were not allowed near those. These became suddenly prisoners of war. But | was delighted to hear it. | think they should have killed more Germans. Are you asking me now whether | still -- now, | don't hate the Germans who were born after the war and have nothing to do with it. | mean, obviously, emotionally -- even emotionally, | don't hate them. But | have not forgiven the Germans who were involved in it. And, by the way, | didn't read the book by Goldhagen, and | don't know how factual. | don't know, but I'll tell you this: He is absolutely right when he says that many, many, many more Germans knew about what was happening, benefited from it, and were participators to the Holocaust. There is no -- | don't, | have no doubt about it. | am not a historian, but | saw enough. The German soldiers didn't have to kill us. The Germans -- my God, it happened in my own house. A month after the war broke out, a German bitch came in with two SS men or soldiers, and they took everything out of our house. And what do you think these people did with all the things that they took from German homes? They sent it back to Germany. How did the Germans suddenly get all these things? Insofar as I'm concerned, to me, the German nation was collectively guilty. They followed Hitler, they did it. But | don't hate the Germans because they have blonde hair or blue eyes or black hair. | hate the Germans for what they did, that's different. | don't like Farakan, not because he's black. | hate Farakan for what he's preaching, that's different. When I'm talking about tolerance, I'm talking about treating people as human beings. But | will tell you this: I'm not a Christian, I'm not turning my other cheek, and I'm not forgiving those who hurt me. In that sense, maybe I'm Jewish, yeah. I'm not forgiving the Germans. Let the pope do it; | won't. And if there is a God, | hope there is a God, | also hope there's hell. And in that hell, | hope Hitler is still burning. Do | sound mean? Fine, that's how | feel.

segments.question: When you talk to children in various places, what do they want to know? What do they -- I'm sure it depends on how old they are.
segments.answer: Well, it depends, it depends. And they ask some questions. | will say this: I'm more careful, | wouldn't say what | just told you about Hitler burning in hell to children. You know, you have to be a little more -- although | tell the children that | have not forgiven the German people who did it, those who did it. And | may also say that if God wants to forgive them, that's his business but I'm not. You know, that's -- children ask very interesting questions, very often what they will do, and this is so touching. They'll come over and they'll say to me, they'll say to me, "Do you have children?" And I'll say, "Yes." And they'll say, "That's good, so you have somebody you can love now." Which is really very touching.

segments.question: Is there anything else?
segments.answer: No. | don't think so. | think | talked more than enough.

data: Okay. This is the end of this is the third tape. This is the end of the interview with Bella Tovey on June 10th, 1996 at her home in Silver Spring, Maryland. And I'm Nina Ellis for the Holocaust Museum. Conclusion of interview.
